name: Paroxysmal Hemicrania Continua with Trigeminal Neuralgia Overlap
chief_complaint: I get these sudden, excruciating headaches on one side of my head, and sometimes my face feels like it's being stabbed with electricity.
symptoms: Lancinating facial pain triggered by light touch
prognosis: Chronic condition with excellent response to indomethacin, though neuralgic component may require long-term management. Complete remission occurs in <10% of cases.
description: A rare primary headache disorder combining features of paroxysmal hemicrania (indomethacin-responsive unilateral headache with autonomic features) and trigeminal neuralgia. The pathophysiology involves both trigeminovascular activation and trigeminal nerve hypersensitivity. Attacks are strictly unilateral, with pain maximal in the V1 distribution but radiating to V2/V3 territories.
risk_factors: Neurovascular compression seen in some cases
